content.text: This section focuses on how to configure BPO to use any of the following external authentication systems: RADIUS (through the BPO API), LDAP (through a command line interface), or TACACS (through a command line interface).
content.header: Configuring BPO to use an external authentication server

content.text: The following procedure describes how RADIUS and LDAP authenticates its users in Blue Planet:
The below section describes Data Synchronization procedure:
The below section describes procedure to authenticate with RADIUS/LDAP server:
Review these important notes before configuring RADIUS or LDAP on the Blue Planet server:
You can configure a RADIUS server for BPO by performing the following procedure.
The BP User details, including passwords, are stored on the BPO database.

BPO performs authentication (checks the user’s password) against the local BPO database. With RADIUS mode enabled, BPO delegates authentication (password checking) to an external RADIUS server. BPO creates a local user, but without a password entry. This way the UAC user interface can list users, but does not allow setting of passwords for RADIUS users.

Local and RADIUS users can both exist in the same UAC instance, but not with the same usernames. UAC can also optionally accept authorization data from RADIUS. Authorization data is used to assign a list of rules to the user. Without the optional RADIUS authorization mode, the UAC administrator can:

Two RADIUS profiles (primary and backup) and two TACACS are automatically created as part of BPO installation. You need to update their default configuration to setup the external RADIUS system as the authentication service for BPO.

In order to configure a primary and backup RADIUS server for BPO, you need to retrieve the uuid of the two default BPO RADIUS configuration profiles and then, for each of them, perform the configuration (IP, and so on) as indicated in the steps in this section.
Before you start, make sure that:

Any misconfiguration or unreachability of RADIUS servers being configured with this procedure can block access to BPO. So it is recommended that you keep the admin user (local to BPO and having Application admin and sysadmin roles) credentials handy to recover from such a situation.

This is a Multi-Valued attribute for inclusion in Access-Accept messages. If the attribute is present more than once in the Access-Accept, BPO adds the roles together.

Acceptable values are comma-separated strings matching (case-sensitively) any roles defined in BPO (these can be retrieved from the API with 'GET /tron/api/v1/roles/?isInternal=false'). Leading and trailing whitespace is removed and values that are not mapped to existing roles in BPO are ignored.

When a user tries to log in with RADIUS enabled, the user object is updated if RADIUS authentication is successful. UAC only communicates with RADIUS during password-based authentication. The token created during user login expires after 24 hours or a configured timeout. Disabling the user in RADIUS does not cause the token to expire before the timeout. After the token has expired, the user must log in again.
A password-based login attempt updates a RADIUS user’s enable/disable status if that
RADIUS user account’s control attribute indicates disabled or the user is deleted from the RADIUS server.

When RADIUS is enabled, UAC first tries to authenticate with the RADIUS server. You can specify one primary RADIUS server and one backup RADIUS server. When both RADIUS servers are enabled, UAC attempts authentication in order of: primary, secondary, then local.
Get an admin token. Use this to configure RADIUS.

PREFIX=https://localhost/tron  TOKEN=$(curl \              --silent -k \              -H "Content-Type:application/json" \              -d '{"username":"admin","password":"adminpw"}' \              $PREFIX/api/v1/tokens | \                  python -c "import sys, json; print json.load(sys.stdin)['token']")  echo $TOKEN

content.text: curl --silent -k -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" $PREFIX/api/v1/radius-configs  RADIUS_UUID=$(curl \                    --silent -k \                    -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" \                    $PREFIX/api/v1/radius-configs | \                        python -c "import sys, json; print json.load(sys.stdin)['results'][0]['uuid']")  curl \      --silent -k \      -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" \      $PREFIX/api/v1/radius-configs/$RADIUS_UUID | \          python -c "import sys, json, pprint; pprint.pprint(json.load(sys.stdin))"
content.header: Display the current state of the RADIUS configuration

header: Configuring multi-tenant access for LDAP users

content.text: This section describes how to configure administrative rights for an individual LDAP user to enable access to a custom set of multiple tenants or sub-tenants. This capability allows users to temporarily change the admin rights of an LDAP user from one set of multiple tenants into another set of multiple tenants by updating a setting in the LDAP account of the associated employee.
content.header: Configuring multi-tenant access for LDAP users

content.text: For example, employee A has admin rights to Tenant1, Tenant2 and Tenant3; while employee B has admin rights to Tenant4 and Tenant5. These rights are set in each employee’s LDAP account. When employee B goes on vacation, an administrator can change employee A’s LDAP account temporarily to allow admin rights to Tenant4 and Tenant5 until employee B returns from vacation.

To accept a Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) servers authorization, Tron requires an additional support. A newly configured API allows the administrator to control the interaction between Tron and the SAML server.
The following table lists the terminologies for SAML configuration and their descriptions:
It is an open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between parties.
It is a system entity for SAML identity provider that issues authentication assertions in conjunction with a single sign-on (SSO) server.
It is a system entity for SAML service provider that receives and accepts authentication assertions from a single sign-on (SSO) server.

A SAML artifact or HTTP artifact is a binding in which a SAML request or response (or both) is transmitted by reference by using a unique identifier. In case of Tron, you should care only about the response artifact.
A dollar sign($) and a word indicates a variable.

◦ $TOKEN = TOKEN=$(curl --silent -k -H "Content-Type:application/json" -d '{"username":"admin","password":"adminpw"}' $PREFIX/api/v1/tokens | python -c "import sys, json; print json.load(sys.stdin)['token']")
Greater Than or Less Than(<>) indicate that you need to supply the info indicated within the
is added to the end of some calls to format the return data. It is not needed.

For BluePlanet product installation with Geographical Redundancy, BluePlanet recommends applying OS patches to the backup site first and verifying whether the GR synchronization status is healthy before patching the primary site.

Operating system (OS) hardening is a set of procedures or configuration settings applied to the system. This allows the system to comply with specific security policies restricting access to resources in the environment. The Center for Internet Security (CIS) provides benchmark documentation that lists the best practices to secure the system. Blue Planet uses these benchmarks to secure systems that are used for product testing and to ensure they will operate properly in a hardened environment.
Blue Planet Orchestration (BPO) is tested against all CIS recommendations (Level 1 and 2, Scored and Unscored) from the following benchmarks:
Use these recommendations to apply any hardening on the host OS of any system running BPO. Hardening outside of these recommendations will be considered unsupported.
The following sections will detail the steps to follow for a hardened system as well as exceptions to the
Below is the steps for installing BP products in a hardened environment is the following:
Although the system requires a reboot after the Bundle installation and hardening step, the system reboot can also be done after completing both the steps together.
Do not apply hardening after the product has been installed without consulting BP
Support. The System Bundle and the BP Installer make modifications to the hardening to all the products for proper functioning
Use of a pre-hardened image (eg. AWS CIS AMI) is supported.
Some CIS recommendations require special consideration when applied to Blue Planet Orchestration (BPO).
